ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to write more evocatively and powerfully. I developed a personal narrative voice for which I am extremely grateful to Anne.
We develop concrete writing and grammar skills in this course.

My writing skills improved immensely. I learned so many different ways to think about and improve my writing structure, style, and voice. Anne knows what she's doing, and her method of teaching works!

Wow where to even start. This class is set up to facilitate learning all the time through the readings, critiques, and reading your classmates' essays on Canvas too. I learned so much about my own strengths and weaknesses as a writer, my writing process, and the ingredients that make up a compelling personal essay. Most of all, I gained a lot of confidence as a writer and built up my toolbox of writing techniques and craft.

How to even begin.. I learned such a broad scope of life and writing skills from this course. Not only did I grow exponentially as a writer, editor, and reader, but within this community of talented, open, and warm writers, I found myself growing within my relationships and in my own identity.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: The sheer volume of writing one must do. There is simply no other way to improve than to... do. Anne urges us ever onwards in our writing by giving us ample opportunities to, well, write!

Weaknesses: The course is organized, it seemed to me, in a very despairing way. "Loss," "Pain," and "Pandemic" were some of the few topics we had to write about. I wish we had corresponding topics of "Discovery," "Joy," and "Laughter" or something like this. To be fair, we did have "Love" but in my mind, this is close but no cigar. My only point is that I wish the course gave equal space to write about happy and joyous things (which are an equal, if not bigger, part of one's life) as it did to write about sad things.

The class is at its strongest when we're looking at texts and determining what makes them good or uninteresting. The class is at its weakest when we veer away from the concrete skills to add to our writer's toolbox.

The greatest strength of this course is the incredible writing community. Getting to read everyone else's work and learn from it was invaluable and I think this is what made the course! Honestly, I cannot think of many weaknesses of the course except that I wish it was in person!

Strengths: Annie puts so much thought and care into the syllabus and the class. I've never had a professor so personally invested in their students. The biweekly one-on-one conferences are especially helpful as you get to line edit your essays with Anne and talk through your stylistic choices with her. Anne also encourages a friendly and supportive environment in the class so there were never feelings of competitiveness reading and commenting (only positive things!) on classmates' essays on Canvas was one of my favorite parts of the class. With a couple of minor exceptions, all of the readings are fabulous, and most of the essays/books were works I would've liked to read in my free time anyway. The workload for this class is definitely no joke but for me, it was a valuable opportunity to focus on my writing intensively since my major is not creative-writing-related at all. The time and work investment was definitely worth the growth I experienced both personally and as a writer.
Weaknesses: The essays, readings, critiques, author presentation, and Canvas posts can add up. The workload is high (but worth it!). The seminars are long and involve a lot of mini lectures from Anne. Sometimes the discussions felt a little forced/overly guided.

I learned the most from the peers in my coursea group of such diverse writers from all differing backgrounds, identities, interests, and writing styles. That's the most important part of the course, I think: how much we all drew from each other and supported each other.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: As far as Covid is concerned, this course was standard. It was virtual. I don't think it could've been improved.

Anne did everything she could to facilitate bonding and learning in our class, despite the pandemic. We had weekly walks with our critique partners, virtual trivia nights a couple times a month, and an in person social distanced picnic at the end of the year!

The one-on-one conferences with Anne Fadiman, I think, were some of the most successful parts of online learning. However, I wished we could have gathered for in-person social gatherings, as over Zoom, these didn't work as well.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I recommend Writing About Oneself conditionally. The opportunity to write about personal events is a huge one. But it can sometimes be frustrating, if you are a hopeful and happy person, to be constantly surrounded with readings that deal with authors' pain, and loss, and death. To be fair, there were some humorous and witty and happy pieces, but really not very many. If this is unproblematic, then onwards! This course is for you. Frankly, the sadness that we had to read dogged me while I was reading, but when I was in class it faded behind what was a dynamic and fun weekly lesson.

Yes! It is a lot of reading, and a lot of writing back to back, so definitely do take this course when you have the space in your schedule (and mental space) to really give it quite a bit of energy, but it's worth it.
yes

I would recommend this courseinteresting texts, useful tools for writing, and Anne Fadiman is very kind. One thing about the workload: It's not the kind of course in which you can do it all of the homework in a day or two if you go hard. There are a lot of little assignments that basically necessitate you working on the class a little everyday, or 5 out of 7 days of the week. You get used to it, and I found the work fulfilling, but just know that it's a different kind of high workload than your average class. 

Btw, it's not the end of the world if you don't get into this class. Don't build this up to be the end-all, be-all. There are many good teachers with inspiring classes.
Absolutely! Every student should take this class, if possible!

YES!!! If you have the opportunity to take WaO, do it! I entered the class with a lot of insecurities about my own writing, and the group of students in the class was so extremely talented that I was intimidated at first. But this class really taught me that each person has a distinct voice and writing style that it is impossible to compare! You'll learn so much from Anne, your classmates, and the readings. It's rare to find a class where you can engage directly with your peers' writing, and I felt like reading other WaOers' essays each week taught me just as much (if not more) than the seminars and syllabus readings. The essay prompts provoke a lot of reflection and introspection that is always valuable in the nonstop world of Yale. Where/when else can you write for fun, read amazing works by your talented classmates, and learn from a gracious and wise professor? I'm a senior and this was probably the best class I've taken at Yale.
I would recommend this to anyone interested in growing exponentially as a writer. If so, this is the course for you: don't be afraid to take on the challenge, because it's all worth it in the end.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual seminar, virtual conferences
Walks with critique partner
Virtual seminar
